message: Wound down 2016 with my grandkids and a deck of cards on the farm. Wishing every Montanan a #HappyNewYear!
2016 has been a year for the books! Here’s a brief review of what we accomplished over these last 12 months & what we have left to do. #mtpol #HappyNewYear!

I want to congratulate our state legislators on kicking off their first day of session. It's going to be a busy 90 days – trust me, I've been there – but if everyone commits to working together for all Montanans, we can make our state an even better place for the next generation. #mtpol #mtleg

We recently passed bipartisan legislation that ensures major infrastructure projects will only use iron and steel that is made here in America by American workers.  It is time to start investing in our country again. https://sen.gov/VLXP

We need more transparency and accountability in government, not less. That’s why I was outraged by the House’s decision to gut the Office of Congressional Ethics and I’m glad they’ve decided to reverse course. Sunshine is the best disinfectant—Americans know that, and they made their voices heard.
Today we kicked off a new session of Congress. This year I look forward to working with Republicans, Democrats, and Independents to increase opportunities for the next generation of Montanans.

Today I met with Secretary of Homeland Security nominee, General John Kelly, to discuss the unique security threats that face rural states like ours. We had a very productive discussion about our shared commitment to working across the aisle to strengthen national security.  http://www.tester.senate.gov/?p=press_release&id=4918

It’s true! I started meeting with President-elect Trump’s cabinet nominees this week to make sure they understand the issues that matter most to Montanans. So I’ve created a portal where folks can submit their questions and concerns about each nominee. Your feedback will help shape our discussions and help me determine whether to support these nominees.   Submit your feedback here: http://www.tester.senate.gov/?p=press_release&id=4900

Today I met with Betsy DeVos, President-elect Trump’s nominee to lead the U.S. Department of Education. As a former teacher, school board member, and public school graduate, I know how important PUBLIC education is. It’s the basis of our democracy and it is the reason why our country has been the leader of the free world for decades. https://sen.gov/5ZR8

The Senate is moving forward on a plan that would repeal healthcare coverage, and cost folks in Lincoln County $2.5 million alone. So today I met with folks in Libby and Kalispell to talk about #WhatsAtRisk if Congress repeals healthcare coverage, without debating a replacement plan to insure the thousands of Montanans who are covered by the ACA.

We must hold our leaders accountable to the highest ethical standards possible.  It’s critical that all of the President-elect’s nominees go through ethics reviews to ensure they are qualified to serve Montana and this nation.

“A big problem with Washington, D.C. right now is that they don’t understand where we live,” Gleason said, as much of the room, including Tester, nodded. “They think Buffalo, New York is rural. They don’t understand the distance and the time it takes to get to a hospital here if these smaller facilities go away.” #WhatsAtRisk

Had a great meeting this week with General Michael Linnington, the new CEO of the Wounded Warrior Project. As the Ranking Member of the Veterans Affairs Committee, I look forward to working closely with him to ensure our vets get the care they’ve earned and deserve.

I heard a lot of uncertainty from patients and providers during my health care listening sessions across the state this weekend, so I wanted to give you all a quick update on what’s going on here in the Senate. Congress is moving forward on a plan to gut the ACA, without proposing any replacement to insure the thousands of Montanans who would lose their coverage if we go back to the old health care system.   So I ask the folks running Congress: Where is your plan?    Right now, you have none and Montanans have made it clear that it's threatening the health of their families. #WhatsAtRisk

As Congressional leaders ready their plan to end Medicare and Medicaid as we know them, I stand today with hundreds of thousands of Montanans whose health insurance is on the chopping block. Seniors are scared that Congress will take away the coverage that they’ve paid into and counted on their whole lives; and hardworking parents are terrified that their kids won’t be able to see a doctor.  I’m here to tell them that I will fight tooth & nail to strengthen these programs, not destroy them. #mtpol #WhatsAtRisk

I met with Senator Sessions last week to ask him about his longstanding history of opposing important civil liberties—including his opposition to the Violence Against Women Act and the Lilly Ledbetter Fair Pay Act, as well as his vocal support for the Patriot Act and other government surveillance programs that infringe on Montanans' right to privacy. https://sen.gov/NZXY

Today the U.S. Department of the Interior announced the cancellation of the final two oil and gas leases in the Badger-Two Medicine. This is a momentous day for both the Blackfeet Nation and Montanans everywhere. https://sen.gov/WM8Q  Photo courtesy of Tony Bynum Photography.

Today I questioned General John Kelly during his confirmation hearing for Secretary of Homeland Security. He was honest, open, transparent and direct about how he hopes to protect our country and secure our borders. He did admit to knowing more about the southern border than he does the northern, but I think he’ll be a quick study—especially after he offered to visit Montana this year. I told him I’d definitely take him up on that.   (cc: Senator Heidi Heitkamp for a great North Dakota joke)

President-elect Trump has finally announced his nominee for Secretary of the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs. As Ranking Member of the Senate Veterans Affairs Committee, I plan on meeting with Dr. Shulkin very soon to discuss how we can improve care at the VA—especially for veterans in Montana.
As the Senate debates the future of our health care system, I took to the Senate floor today to provide a voice for the folks in rural states like Montana. #WhatsAtRisk https://sen.gov/MXZ3

Today I questioned Dr. Ben Carson, President-elect Trump’s nominee for Secretary of the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development. If confirmed, I asked him to increase access to affordable housing, protect the 30-year mortgage, and to come visit Montana so he can better understand the housing difficulties in Indian Country.  https://sen.gov/3XXO

The ultimate irony? As I introduce my rural call completion bill for the THIRD time since joining the Senate, New Yorkers can now make calls and browse the web as they wait for the subway. If we can keep city folks connected—even when they’re underground—there should be no reason we can’t #ConnectMT.   https://sen.gov/666J

Today I visited the Last Chance Pub & Cider Mill in Billings. The owners, Sam and Lindsay Hoffman, also own Red Lodge Ales and decided to open up the Mill this past November. I was pleased to work with these folks to help get their business up and rolling. Always excited to see a homegrown small business thriving!

I’m excited to announce that I will be serving as Ranking Member of the Senate Homeland Security Appropriations Subcommittee this Congress. As a leader on this Committee, I will work with both Republicans and Democrats on the Committee to strengthen national security while eliminating the bureaucratic waste that has saddled our kids with truckloads of debt. https://sen.gov/0XXN

Thank you for reaching out with your comments about my vote this week and the skyrocketing cost of prescription drugs.  President-elect Trump and Senator Bernie Sanders are right that we have to get them under control.  I support importing safe prescription drugs and I’ve voted numerous times to allow it.   But the amendment I voted on this week, which wouldn’t have even changed the law, wasn’t the right solution.  We cannot open the door to a flood of counterfeit medicine that puts our safety and health at risk, and we need to keep working on real ways to bring costs down.
Today I heard the compelling stories of #WhatsAtRisk to mental health care if we repeal the Affordable Care Act.
"Without the Affordable Care Act I would not be walking. Because I had insurance for the first time, I am here today, able to walk." -- Penny Ronning, Billings   #WhatsAtRisk
Today we celebrate a man and a movement that fought for dignity, decency, and a democracy that defends all folks equally. #MLKDay
Today I was honored to stand before the Montana House of Representatives and unveil my plan to #EmployMT. https://sen.gov/JX10 #mtleg

Yesterday I addressed the Montana House of Representatives and introduced my plan to #EmployMT.  This plan will rebuild our infrastructure, create a marketplace for our products, pave the way for innovation, invest in our workforce, and responsibly develop our resources. Most importantly, it will let folks know that Montana is open for business.

As Secretary of Education nominee Betsy DeVos’ confirmation hearing comes to a close, I’ve been soliciting feedback from Montanans about all of President-elect Trump’s nominees, and I have heard from hundreds of folks concerned about her nomination so far. Here are a just a few of those comments—and they're concerns I share as well.

Today Secretary of Health and Human Services nominee Tom Price reaffirmed his desire to repeal the ACA, privatize Medicare, and defund Planned Parenthood. I share many of the same concerns as folks from all over Montana who are very worried about his nomination.

I plan to meet face-to-face with EPA Administrator nominee Scott Pruitt later this afternoon to discuss the many concerns Montanans have about his record. Our state’s natural resources are part of what make Montana the Last Best Place, and we need an Administrator who will protect our outdoor economy for generations to come.

No matter who you voted for or where you think the country is headed—if you’re a Montanan, I’m with you.

I look forward to working with Secretary Mattis and Secretary Kelly to better secure our borders, fight terrorism abroad, and ensure our troops and their families have the resources they need to continue to protect Montana and our nation.

This week I met with Montana-native and NASA Administrator Dava Newman to thank her for advancing our knowledge of science, engineering, and space exploration while inspiring the next generation of girls to reach for the stars like she did.  https://www.nasa.gov/about/highlights/newman_bio.html
There are still more questions than answers when it comes to repealing the ACA. Make sure you share #WhatsAtRisk: https://sen.gov/77ZV

This week I met with students from Havre High School who were in DC. We talked about a whole host of issues, from making higher education more affordable to investing in Montana’s infrastructure to what we can expect from this new Administration. I have to say, these kids knew their stuff.

When Amazon.com announced its plan to create 100,000 U.S. jobs over the next 18 months, I immediately thought of our state’s top-notch workforce, business friendly tax environment, and world-class University system as great reasons to create those jobs right here in Montana. So I wrote Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos a letter to tell him Montana is open for business! #EmployMT   https://sen.gov/77J6

Tonight I voted for Montanans’ right to privacy. We must strengthen our national security, and we do not have to sacrifice our civil liberties in the process.  The type of bulk data collection and mass surveillance that CIA Nominee Mike Pompeo advocates for would hinder every American’s right to privacy.  We can have a safe nation that respects our fundamental freedoms. Both are possible.
I look forward to bringing new Homeland Security Secretary John Kelly to Montana!

Today the Trump Administration decided to limit federal agencies’ ability to communicate with the press and the public. This is not empowering the people of this country. This is stopping the press from doing their job. And this is taking away the transparency we need to hold these agencies accountable. https://sen.gov/RJRY
A federal hiring freeze would disproportionately affect our veterans’ ability to find good-paying jobs and get the care and benefits they have earned. https://sen.gov/2OW5

President Trump's hiring freeze will disproportionately affect our veterans’ ability to find good-paying jobs and get the care and benefits they have earned. That's why I'm asking the Administration to exempt the VA and veterans from this hiring freeze: https://sen.gov/2OW5. But you don't have to just take my word for it...
It’s been a chilly few weeks here in the Treasure State, but a little frost can’t stop the flattop. #FlattopFriday

Thanks to legislation we recently passed, the VA announced it will now cover fertility services for veterans with service-connected disabilities who want to start a family. I am proud that those who have defended our families can now build families of their own.    https://sen.gov/MXMO
This is one of the most humbling parts of my job.

Just wrapped up three more health care listening sessions in Sidney, Plentywood and Glasgow, bringing the total to well over a dozen. And the one thing I’ve heard each & every time is that folks don’t want Washington to repeal their health care without a plan in place to cover them and their families. We all know our current health care system is far from perfect, but repealing all the progress we’ve made is reckless and irresponsible.  Let’s work together to build on that progress, improve access to care, lower costs, and fight for a healthier Montana. #WhatsAtRisk

Today I voted to confirm Elaine Chao as Secretary of Transportation. I will work with Secretary Chao to invest in our infrastructure and rebuild Montana’s roads, bridges, and highways—an integral part of my plan to #EmployMT.

The folks who try to transfer our public lands were once again overruled by those of us who hunt, fish, and float. Outdoorsmen and women across the west spoke up and got Rep. Chaffetz to withdraw his very misguided bill. This is what happens when we all band together and make our voices heard. We won’t stop until every member of Congress commits to keeping our public lands in public hands. #KeepItPublic

But in the Senate he’s voted against providing resources for survivors of domestic abuse, and has been a staunch advocate for bulk data collection and many of the most intrusive aspects of the Patriot Act. The Attorney General must protect & defend the rights of ALL Americans and, based on his track record, I don't think Senator Sessions will do that.

After 75 years, William Gruber’s body will finally be returned to the Boulder Valley thanks to the perseverance of his surviving brothers and some great reporting from the Boulder Monitor. I’m so glad I could help William’s family get the closure they deserve. And I’m deeply grateful that William Gruber will finally get the proper burial—with full military honors—that he earned.

My wife has been my partner throughout my life—we’ve been married almost 40 years.  She works harder than most folks I know and supports me like none other. I support her like none other too. 100 years ago, Butte, America was home to a booming mining community, where hardworking men and women spent long hours building a stronger state. On June 8, 1917, as miners were beginning their shifts, a lantern ignited an exposed cable, causing the mineshaft to fill with fire and toxic gasses. 168 men lost their lives and the Granite Mountain disaster remains the worst hard rock mining disaster in U.S. history. More than 50 years ago, the military conducted top secret weapons testing on thousands of its own men. During these tests—codenamed Project SHAD—military personnel were exposed to high levels of weaponized chemical agents and highly toxic carcinogens. Billings veteran John Olsen was one of them. Over the last two decades he has grappled with severe respiratory and cardiac issues and battled cancer four different times. Olsen sought treatment for these issues at the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs, but because his medical records related to Project SHAD are still classified, the VA has denied Olsen care. That’s why I introduced a bill to declassify these records and get Olsen the medical care he deserves. This bill, the Gary Deloney and John Olsen Toxic Exposure Declassification Act, was passed by both the House and Senate last week and is now awaiting the President Donald J. Trump's signature.

This tree is more than a symbol of the natural resources the Treasure State has to offer – it represents our shared history, intertwined with our outdoor heritage and our Montana values.

Today the Federal Communications Commission voted to repeal Net Neutrality, which ensures that no matter who you are or how you connect, everyone has equal access to the Internet. Without Net Neutrality we are at the whim of big corporations that can now favor websites that make them a profit, while blocking or slowing down websites that can’t pay their fees. So I’m demanding the FCC listen to the thousands of Montanans who have contacted my office, reverse their decision, and preserve our free and open Internet. Ending Net Neutrality ends the Internet as we know it.

As we wrap up a very busy year, I thought it’d be nice to look back at 2017. So, over the next 10 days I’ll be sharing some of my most liked, shared, and talked about Facebook posts of the year.   Kicking it off at #10 is one of my personal favorites:

#9 - Health care was a defining issue of 2017 and I was proud to join both Republicans and Democrats in defeating scheme after scheme to raise insurance rates, kick millions of Americans off their health plans, and close down rural hospitals. I was equally opposed to the way these bills were written and pushed through—behind closed doors, without public debate, and along strict party lines. That’s why I worked so hard to hold town halls and listening sessions, solicit feedback from folks across the state, and keep you updated on what was going. Our current health care system is far from perfect, but the only way to fix it is by working together.

#8 - From the Women’s March to the #MeToo movement, 2017 was a landmark year for women. So it comes as no surprise that this was one of my most popular posts of the year. From introducing a bill to expand VA services for female veterans to raising awareness about the issues faced by many Native women to defending access to contraceptives, together we fought to make a difference.

#7 - When I became Ranking Member of the Veterans’ Affairs Committee in January I promised to put politics aside and get things done for our veterans. Almost 12 months later, we’ve gotten more bipartisan bills signed into law than I can count on both hands and our committee has become “a case study in Washington working as designed.” It’s something I’m very proud of because our veterans deserve results.

#4 - As a former teacher, board member, and graduate of Montana’s public schools, I know that America is great not in spite of, but because of our public education system. And I know thousands of Montanans agree, because when Betsy DeVos was nominated to lead the U.S. Department of Education I heard from just about all of them. That’s why I spent this year holding her feet to the fire to make sure our public schools didn’t lose out on a single opportunity to succeed.

One thing I’m thankful for is knowing, going into the New Year, TRIO-Upward Bound, University of Montana will be funded. Upward Bound has five decades of success at the University of Montana and has helped generations of Montanans achieve their dreams of earning a college degree. I was proud to fight for Montana's first generation college students this past year and look forward to seeing all they will achieve in the year to come.

#3 - One of the most irresponsible decisions this year was when the U.S. Department of Education refused to fund the TRIO-Upward Bound, University of Montana program because one page of its grant application wasn’t double spaced. If that isn’t Washington dysfunction at its worst, I don’t know what is. After calling out this absurdity, telling the success stories of these students, and introducing legislation to hold Secretary Betsy DeVos accountable, we finally got the DOE to reverse its decision and fund the program for the next five years.
